fields.Acute_plan:
Check weapon type: handgun (low velocity), shotgun (intermediate velocity), assault rifle (high velocity, treat like Gustilo Type III)
CT: if near joints, check for intra-articular fragments.

ABX coverage:
If Gustilo type I and II - ancef
If Gustilo type III - ancef + gentamicin
If farm injuries, heavy contamination, or bowel injuries - ancef + gentamicin + penicillion (clostridium coverage)
If fresh water - ceftazidime/cipro
If salt water - doxycycline + ceftazidime/cipro
If handgun GSW - ancef
Tetanus PPX: Tetanus bacteria commonly found in soil. Ask ED for specific administration.
Direct pressure for hemostasis: Controls most bleeding, no need for tourniquet.
ABI: If pulses aren't palpable manually or Dopplerable. For tibial plateau fx.
Saline load test: 95% sensitivity - 194cc in knee, 40cc in elbow, 30cc in ankle. Anytime there is a laceration over joint. 
Cover in saline-soaked gauze: no evidence for aggressive washout in ED, as it can push debris inward.
Splint: To decrease pain, minimize soft tissue trauma, and stabilize clots.
fields.Follow_up:
Admit to ortho: If isolated fracture
Post for urgent OR: Better outcomes with aggressive I&D within 24hrs

fields.Acute_plan:
Ask symptom timing: acute (within 2 weeks), subacute (1-several months), chronic (several months)
Labs: ESR (90% sensitive, up in acute and chronic), CRP (97% sensitive), WBC (33% sensitive), blood cultures (usually neg, but good if hematogenous spread)
XR: Always get them, but findings only apparent after 2 weeks. Will show bone lucency, osteopenia, periosteal reaction, lysis around hardware.
CT: If nothing on XR, get CT to better visualize necrotic bone
MRI: If nothing on XR and CT, get MRI. Negative rules out osteomyelitis.
Check for sinus tract: If able to probe bone through sinus tract, chronic OM present.
fields.Follow_up:
Medicine service involvement: Majority of the time, will just need IV abx for acute OM. Even if going to OR, will need 24-48 hrs IV abx. 
Admit to ortho and post for OR: If draining sinus tract is present.

fields.Acute_plan:
• Do they have a primary cancer diagnosis?:
• Where is lesion located?:
• Lytic vs blastic? Pathologic fracture or not:
• Need to image full bone because might change operative plan because want to protect entire bone with fixation:
• Getty likes to get MRIs but you should talk to 4th year before getting MRI but when you call 4th year it is something to discuss:

AP, lateral, open-mouth odontoid XRs: Rarely helpful to assess condylar injuries because maxilla and occiput block condyles, mainly for seeing associated injuries.
Get CT:  Must get CT as method of choice.
Conduct neuro exam: full upper and lower extremities, saddle anesthesia, rectal tone, long tract signs (clonus, hyperreflexia, Babinski, Hoffman's) 
Calculate Powels ratio: 
From CT. Distance from basion to posterior arch / Distance from anterior arch to opisthion 
~1 normal, <1 posterior occipitocervical dislocation, >1 anterior occipitocervical dislocation.
Calculate basion-dens interval: From CT. >12mm disassociation.
Get Anderson classification: For occipitocervical fractures. Type I,II,III. Based off CT.
Consider MRI: Discuss with senior. Get if CT shows fracture retropulsion into canal or CT findins suspicious for ligamentous injury (widening of condyle spaces, etc.).
fields.Follow_up:
Trauma service involvement: Considered high energy injury, recommend Aspen collar and observation for 24hrs
Post for urgent OR: C0-2/3 fusion for occipitocervical dissasociation, retropulsion into canal, ligamentous instability

fields.Acute_plan:
Get AP, lateral, and open mouth odontoid XRs: Calculate ADI, SAC, lateral mass displacement from normal XRs. 
Consider flexion-extension views: Required for pre-operative clearance and ideal ADI and SAC, but do not order them in ED without discussion with senior.
Get CT: Method of choice.
Get Landells atlas fracture classification: Based off CT. Type I,II,III.
Calculate ADI: 
From lateral. Distance b/w odontoid and anterior atlas. 
>3mm is unstable in adults, >5mm is unstable in children,  >10mm is indication for surgery in RA
Calculate SAC:
From lateral. Distance b/w odontoid and to posterior atlas.
<13mm is unstable, <14mm is indication for surgery in RA patients.
Calculate sum of both lateral mass displacement: From odontoid view. >7mm indicates transverse ligmanet disruption, is unstable
Ask about adult associated conditions: Down syndrome, RA
Ask about pediatric associated conditions: JRA, Morquio's syndrome, rotatory atlantoaxial subluxation
Assess for other spine injuries: 50% incidence
Conduct neuro exam: full upper and lower extremities, saddle anesthesia, rectal tone, long tract signs (clonus, hyperreflexia, Babinski, Hoffman's) 
Consider MRI: Discuss with senior at this point, if you suspect ligamentous disruption or unstable neuro exam.
fields.Follow_up:
Trauma service involvement: Considered high energy injury, recommend Aspen collar and observation for 24hrs
Post for OR: If unstable ligamentous injury or neuro exam. Post for posterior C1-C2 fusion vs. occipitocervical fusion.

fields.Acute_plan:
Get AP, lateral, and open mouth odontoid XRs: Calculate ADI, SAC from normal XRs. 
Consider flexion-extension views: Required for pre-operative clearance and ideal ADI and SAC, but do not order them in ED without discussion with senior.
Get CT: Method of choice.
Get Anderson and D'Alonzo classification: Based off CT. Type I,II,III.
Assess for os odontoideum: Looks like Type II, may represent old traumatic process.
Get Landells atlas fracture classification: Based off CT. Type I,II,III.
Calculate ADI: 
From lateral. Distance b/w odontoid and anterior atlas. 
>3mm is unstable in adults, >5mm is unstable in children,  >10mm is indication for surgery in RA
Calculate SAC:
From lateral. Distance b/w odontoid and to posterior atlas.
<13mm is unstable, <14mm is indication for surgery in RA patients.
Conduct neuro exam: Full upper and lower extremities, saddle anesthesia, rectal tone, long tract signs (clonus, hyperreflexia, Babinski, Hoffman's)
Consider CT angiogram: Discuss with senior. Required to assess vertebral body if doing  posterior fusion. 
Consider MRI: Discuss with senior. If neurologic symptoms present.
fields.Follow_up:
Trauma service involvement: Considered high energy injury, recommend Aspen collar and observation for 24hrs
Post for OR: Type II fractures. Post for posterior C1-C2 fusion vs anterior odontoid osteosynthesis.

fields.Acute_plan:
Define it: Bilateral C2 pars fractures with C2 subluxation on C3
Get CT: 
Method of choice. 
Identify bilateral C2 pars fractures and measure displacemenet of C2.
Identify possible facet dislocation.
Consider flexion-extension views in ED: 
Discuss with senior.
Will show C2 subluxating off C3. Identify facet dislocation. 
Assess for other spine injuries: 30% concomitant c-spine injuries
Conduct neuro exam: Full upper and lower extremities, saddle anesthesia, rectal tone, long tract signs (clonus, hyperreflexia, Babinski, Hoffman's)
Consider MRA: Discuss with senior. If suspicious for vertebral artery injury.
Consider MRI: Discuss with senioir. If neurological symptoms.
fields.Follow_up:
Trauma service involvement: Considered high energy injury, recommend Aspen collar and observation for 24hrs
Post for OR: Post for possible cervical spine fusion if neurologic symptoms or displacement greater than 3mm.

fields.Acute_plan:
Get CT:
Identify mono vs bilateral facet dislocation
Identify fractures to facets, pedicles, or lamina
Get XR: Non-essential. If unable to get and CT is already completed, then no need to aggresively pursue.
Conduct neuro exam: Full upper and lower extremities, saddle anesthesia, rectal tone, long tract signs (clonus, hyperreflexia, Babinski, Hoffman's)
Consider MRI:
Discuss with senior.
If any neurologic deficits are present in AWAKE patient with facet dislocation, PRIORITY is to reduce dislocation in OR. MRI should be performed AFTER attempt at closed reduction.
However, IMMEDIATELY get MRI for facet dislocations with patient AMS, to assess neurologic compromise since you can't conduct proper neuro exam.
IMMEDIATELY get MRI if patient is going straight to open reduction and surgical stabilization, to assess for disc herniation, which will need to be removed through anterior approach.
fields.Follow_up:
Trauma service involvement: Considered high energy injury, recommend Aspen collar and observation for 24hrs
Post for OR: Post for closed reduction with Gardner-Wells tongs in OR if neurologic symptoms with dislocation present.

fields.Acute_plan:
Get CT: Method of choice to assess for kyphosis to assess stability and any bony retropulsion.
Get standing AP, lateral XRs: Need standing xrays to assess kyphosis, and also to compare during follow-up. 
Get descriptive classification: compression, burst, flexion-distraction, facet dislocation, facet fracture
Conduct neuro exam: Full upper and lower extremities, saddle anesthesia, rectal tone, long tract signs (clonus, hyperreflexia, Babinski, Hoffman's)
Consider MRI:
Discuss with senior.
Get if there are neurologic deficits, particularly as to assess posterior ligamentous complex injury.
fields.Follow_up:
Trauma service involvement: Considered high energy injury, recommend Aspen collar and observation for 24hrs
Post for OR: Post for closed reduction with Gardner-Wells tongs in OR if neurologic symptoms with dislocation present.

fields.Acute_plan:
Define it: Avulsion of anterioinferior corner of vertebral body, due to hyperextension.
Get standing AP/lateral XRs: Identify the triangular shaped (hence 'teardrop') fragment, assess anterior disc space for widening 
Get CT: Method of choice. Identify any other fracture extension.
Conduct neuro exam: Full upper and lower extremities, saddle anesthesia, rectal tone, long tract signs (clonus, hyperreflexia, Babinski, Hoffman's)
Consider central cord syndrome: Associted due to buckling of ligamentum flavum during hyperextension.
Consider MRI:
Discuss with senior.
Get if neuro deficits present or you suspect central cord syndrome.
fields.Follow_up: Discharge in hard cervical collar if no neuro deficits

fields.Acute_plan:
Define it: Avulsion of anterioinferior corner of vertebral body, due to hyperextension.
Get standing AP/lateral XRs: Identify the triangular shaped (hence 'teardrop') fragment, assess anterior disc space for widening 
Get CT: Method of choice. Identify any other fracture extension.
Conduct neuro exam: Full upper and lower extremities, saddle anesthesia, rectal tone, long tract signs (clonus, hyperreflexia, Babinski, Hoffman's)
Consider central cord syndrome: Associted due to buckling of ligamentum flavum during hyperextension.
Consider MRI:
Discuss with senior.
Get if neuro deficits present or you suspect central cord syndrome.
fields.Follow_up: Discharge in hard cervical collar if no neuro deficits

fields.Acute_plan: Define it: Vertebral fracture with compromise of the anterior and middle column  Get full spine CT: Method of choice. Full spine needed b/c 20% concomitant spine fractures. Get full spine AP/lateral XRs: Mainly used for follow-up in clinic to assess alignment. Conduct neuro exam: Full upper and lower extremities, saddle anesthesia, rectal tone, long tract signs (clonus, hyperreflexia, Babinski, Hoffman's) Consider post-void residuals: If concerned for neurogenic bladder Get MRI: Discuss with senior. Required for neurologic deficits or obtunded patient. Will likely need MRI to ensure stability of posterior ligamentous complex. Calculate TLICS: TLICS calculator <4 is non-surgical, 4 is surgical or non-surgical, >4 is surgical
fields.Follow_up: Discharge in hard cervical collar if no neuro deficits

fields.Acute_plan:
Define it: lumbar spine flexes, causing anterior column to fail in compression and middle/posterior columns to fail in tension
Get CT:
Method of choice. A Chance fracture will show posterior column distraction.
Note degree of fracture extension and any retropulsion into canal.
Get AP/lateral lumbar XRs:
For comparison of alignment in later outpatient follow-up.
Cosider flexion-extension views:
Non-essential. Do not get in ED. Discuss with senior.
Conduct neuro exam: Full upper and lower extremities, saddle anesthesia, rectal tone, long tract signs (clonus, hyperreflexia, Babinski, Hoffman's)
Consider post-void residuals: If concerned for neurogenic bladder
Get MRI:
Discuss with senior.
If a Chance fracture, always get an MRI regardless of neuro deficits, to evaluate damage to PLC.
fields.Follow_up:
Trauma service involvement: Considered high energy injury, recommend Aspen collar and spine precautions for 24hours
TLSO if no neuro deficits and no damage in PLC
Post for OR: If neuro deficits and any damage to PLC, post for anterior and posterior spinal instrumented fusion

fields.Acute_plan: Define it: Thoracolumbar fracture associated with posterior facet dislocation Get CT: Method of choice. Note degree of fracture extension and dislocation into canal. Conduct neuro exam: Full upper and lower extremities, saddle anesthesia, rectal tone, long tract signs (clonus, hyperreflexia, Babinski, Hoffman's) Consider post-void residuals: If concerned for neurogenic bladder Get MRI: Discuss with senior. A thoracolumbar fracture-dislocation requires immediate MRI to evaluate PLC. Calculate TLICS: TLICS calculator <4 is non-surgical, 4 is surgical or non-surgical, >4 is surgical Get AP/lateral lumbar XRs: Non-essential. Get it when possible. For comparison of alignment in later outpatient follow-up.
fields.Follow_up:
Trauma service involvement: Considered high energy injury, recommend Aspen collar and spine precautions for 24hours
Post for OR: Always post these for the OR for posterior spinal instrumented fusion. Jackson frame.

fields.Acute_plan:
Define traumatic vs osteoporotic: If osteoporotic, considered a spine fragility fracture
Get full spine XRs: 
20% concomitant spine injuries
Define degree of kyphosis
Define degree of vertebral body collapse:
>50% loss considered unstable
Get CT: Method of choice
Get full medical workup: ESR, CRP, CBC, BMP, urine, serum electrophoresis to rule out infection vs tumor
Conduct neuro exam: Full upper and lower extremities, saddle anesthesia, rectal tone, long tract signs (clonus, hyperreflexia, Babinski, Hoffman's)
Consider post-void residuals: If concerned for neurogenic bladder
Consider MRI:
Discuss with senior.
Not usually indicated, unless there are neuro deficits.
fields.Follow_up:
Trauma service involvement: Considered high energy injury, recommend Aspen collar and spine precautions for 24hours
Discharge in TLSO brace.

fields.Injury: Cauda equina syndrome and lumbar stenosis
fields.Acute_plan:
Get full spine MRI / CT myelogram:
If consulting service is asking for cauda equina workup, they MUST have MRI before you see the consult. 
Alternative is a CT myelogram in patients unable to get MRI (pacemaker).
Discuss with senior.
Evaluate for tandem stenosis in cervical spine: 20% incidence of cervical stenosis
Make NPO:
If any concern for cauda equina, immediately order NPO.
Conduct neuro exam: Full upper and lower extremities, saddle anesthesia, rectal tone, long tract signs (clonus, hyperreflexia, Babinski, Hoffman's)
Consider post-void residuals: If concerned for neurogenic bladder
fields.Follow_up: Immeidately post for posterior surgical decompression and fusion for urgent OR within 48 hours

fields.Acute_plan:
Get ESR, CRP, WBC, blood cultures:
Hold antibiotics:
Make NPO:
Get MRI w/ contrast:
Consulting service MUST have MRI if consulting for vertebral osteomyelitis
Conduct neuro exam: Full upper and lower extremities, saddle anesthesia, rectal tone, long tract signs (clonus, hyperreflexia, Babinski, Hoffman's)
Consider post-void residuals: If concerned for neurogenic bladder
fields.Follow_up: IV antibiotics on medicine service: Most cases

fields.Acute_plan:
Get ESR, CRP, WBC, blood cultures:
Hold antibiotics:
Make NPO:
Get MRI w/ contrast:
Consulting service MUST have MRI if consulting for vertebral osteomyelitis
Conduct neuro exam: Full upper and lower extremities, saddle anesthesia, rectal tone, long tract signs (clonus, hyperreflexia, Babinski, Hoffman's)
Consider post-void residuals: If concerned for neurogenic bladder

Get ESR, CRP, WBC, blood cultures:
Hold antibiotics:
Make NPO:
Get MRI w/ contrast:
Consulting service MUST have MRI if consulting for vertebral osteomyelitis
Conduct neuro exam: Full upper and lower extremities, saddle anesthesia, rectal tone, long tract signs (clonus, hyperreflexia, Babinski, Hoffman's)
Consider post-void residuals: If concerned for neurogenic bladder

AP/lateral of hip, ful length femur, knee XR:
Check for any other fractures:
Get fluoro:
Check for dislocation direction:
Reduce:
Post-reduction AP pelvis XR:
Post-reduction fine-cut CT:
Check hip stability:
Place in knee immobilizer:
Skeletal traction:
fields.Follow_up:
TTWB and discharge: If isolated, stable, congrugent hip after reduction
Admission to ortho: If fracture-dislocation, incarcerated fragment in hip, unstable hip after reduction

fields.Acute_plan:
• Do I have adequate xrays? Need a good lateral for type 2’s:
• To start out you should get ipsilateral forearm xrays, 10% incidence:
• Neurovascular status, Need to take down splint and check skin and pulse, compartment check- no pulse, but good cap refill is OK in kids but make senior resident aware. Admit o/n for NV checks:
• Extension type- AIN most common nerve injury:
• NPO status? No need for lab work:
• Long Arm Splint:
• Consent/Mark Patient :
• “If I have to push on it, it gets pinned” – G. Thompson:
• SPECIAL NOTE: Regardless of displacement of SCHFx, a patient who has an ipsilateral forearm fracture MUST be admitted for compartment checks as there is a 33% incidence of compartment syndrome:

fields.Injury: Distal radius / Both bone forearm fracture
fields.Acute_plan:
• Neurovascular status:
• NPO status? No need for lab work:
• Does it need a reduction with full sedation or morphine versed:
• C- Arm,  finger traps, hematoma block, measure out splint on opposite arm so when pediatric ER is ready to go, you are ready to go:
• Sugar tong splint, get a good mold, use palms, amount of sup/pro depends on fx stability (prepare for cast index as pimp question):
• You may want to use fluoro to know where to put your hands, recreate deformity SLOWLY and controlled, don’t forget to use pronation/supination to your advantage when reducing:
• Post reduction films:

• AP pelvis, bilateral hip films:
• Get endocrine labs (anesthesia may obtain labs in OR to avoid sticking awake child):
• Post, mark and consent (add possible CRPP contralateral hip):

• Examine entire extremity:
• XR, CBC, ESR, CRP:
• Kocher’s criteria (NWB, Temp >38.5, ESR >40, WBC >12k) :
o 4/4=99%, :
o ¾=93%, :
o 2/4= 40% (more likely to be transient synovitis):
• If indicated, most adults go straight to U/S-guided aspiration, kids get an MRI to also r/o OM, often of the entire leg because exam is often unable to localize their pain (especially if very young):
• They stay in the ED until they can get their MRI under sedation or they get admitted to Peds until they can. :

• While on the phone ask them to call for traction cart and a traction bed if shaft fracture. This takes time get them to start working on it immediately:
• Need full femur films:
• What is the age and weight of the patient?:
o If patient is under 3 years old, recommend NAT workup because it is hospital policy.  If <100lbs->flexinails; >100lbs->IM nail:
• What kind of fracture pattern? Transverse vs spiral etc:
• Neurovascular status:
• Does it need Skin traction?:
o Diaphyseal fractures usually do:
o I use ~1 pound per year of age up to 5 pounds:
o Go to cast room before seeing patient and bring down the skin traction :
• Almost all distal physeal femur fractures need operative fixation because of risk of deformity:
• Consent and mark:

• Find ED charge nurse and have them work on getting a hospital bed; tell them the patient can NOT leave the ED until this happens:
• Find trauma/ED resident and nurse taking care of patient to start coordinating sedation:
• Call (page?) 30455 yourself to work on getting the bed (has not worked on the weekends for me):
• Call 43401 to have the traction cart brought up to the ED (there may also be traction setups in the Lakeside 60 call room and/or Tower 6 call room):
• Order a portable scout XR of the knee to ensure you aren't about to place traction through a distal femur fx:
• Go to the OR and get 2 smooth steinmann pins/wires (2.2mm) which are individually peel packed and on a rack across from rooms 6/7 in the core:
• If the patient has a huge leg you may need to open the Synthes 6.5 set to get out the longer 2.8 steinmann pin:
• There is also a big metal drawer/tool chest looking thing in the core between OR 6/7, the traction bows are in the bottom drawer, grab one of those. There are also sterile traction bows if you can't find one there:
• Get the mini driver and battery x2 (ask the person in the core and they may have you sign it out):
• You can also get a wire cutter for extra style points so you don't leave the sharp tip on the pin after you place it:
• In the ED (cabinet in trauma bay is easiest) get sterile gloves, chloraprep, a small scalpel (11 or 15 blade), some kerlix:
• Ideally transfer the patient to the hospital bed prior to doing the reduction and placing the traction pin  :
• If the bed does not arrive in a timely manner either do the reduction and hang traction off the end of the cart the patient is on, using stacks of blankets to prop up the rope and stabilize the leg; or tape the leg a shit ton to the other leg at the ankle/foot with a blanket in between the ankles:
• Place the traction bar setup on the hospital bed (simple frame at the foot of the bed with an extension that you angle off the bed away from the patient at approx 45 deg angle with the pulley at the top for the rope):
• make your rope with loops at both ends, one loop needs to be large enough to fit over the key on the traction bow, the other just attaches to the hook on the weight carrier
• do your reduction of the dislocated hip
• you will often have someone holding traction on the foot for you while you do the next part since you just reduced the hip and it is likely unstable (main reason why you would do this in the first place) 
• if placing skeletal traction through the proximal tibia (not common) make sure to do a full knee ligamentous exam; if unstable, then no traction
• placing blanket bumps under the entire leg will help elevate it so you have more of a straight shot across
• palpate your landmarks on the leg, I like to mark things out (superior aspect of the patella and go 2-3 fingers proximal to that so you're out of the joint)
• prep both the medial and lateral sides of the leg/distal femur; better to over prep so you can feel around and whatnot
• make sure to look how the foot is sitting (int/ext rotation) so that when you pull traction and straighten the leg you don't then realize that you put your pin in at a 30 deg angle
• make a knick in the skin on the medial side; only about 0.5cm (neurovascular structures over the posteromedial femur; which is why you go known to unknown)
• spread down to bone with a hemostat (very small area)
• place pin onto bone and feel the anterior and posterior borders of the femur, you want to center it 
• drive the pin through the bone parallel to the knee joint
• when the pin starts to tent the skin on the lateral side, stop, make another very small knick in the skin, and finish driving the pin through
• alternatively you can just stick the pin straight through skin down to bone and use a hemostat on the lateral side to tension the skin as it starts to poke through. If you do this make sure the skin isn't binding on the pin as your drill it through
• lift the leg up by the pin and make sure it feels like the pin is through bone, and not just muscle/skin
• tension the bow onto the pin by placing the pin ends in the slots and then turning the key on the end of it
• attach the rope to the bow and the weights (usually about 20 lbs for an average adult)
• slowly release manual traction on the leg now that you have the weights in place and make sure that you don't feel the hip slide back out
• snip off the sharp end of the wire and dispose of it properly; you can cover the ends with blood collection tubes or the little sharps cover that comes in the ABG kit (nurse can get this for you)
• wrap the ends of the wire between the bow and the leg with kerlix for padding
• make sure the bow is not resting on the patient's anterior tibia (skin breakdown); may have to pad this with ABDs and/or adjust the angle of the pulley at the end of the bed
• you can either get an AP pelvis to confirm reduction, or go straight to CT if you are confident
• post-reduction CT; will likely have to help transfer the patient and maybe hold the traction while they get the CT
• go see the other 3 consults that piled up while you were doing all that

Daily Schedule
6PM-7PM: Receive sign-out from dayfloat and help them finish up.
7PM-430AM: Consults.
430AM: No matter how busy I am, generally come back up to the callroom to finish email.
5AM: Send email.
545AM: Send group text to Dr. Sontich/Wetzel/Ochenjele about operative traumas. Just send
pictures, and I usually copy the HPI/Plan from my call email. They will expect you to know
things about cases added on during the day too, so be prepared.
6AM-7AM: Staff your consults with the attendings. Pretty much all of my staffing was via text.
Just send pics/copy call email.
7AM-8AM: Signout to dayfloat, finish up your work. Go to lecture only if all the other stuff is
tied up.
